title: Marie Wallace to Walt Whitman, [undated]
text: Dear Sir:I must of late by chance, with an extract from your writings,—with which as a whole I have to confess I am but little acquainted. This is the passage, "I think I could turn and live with the animals, they are so placid and self-contained"—and so on, ending with—"Not one is responsible or industrious over the whole earth."That is all there was, and it is great! I love animals, and understand them well, feeling a kinship to them as a rule, I have to human feeling too, I acknowledge more keenly to their sufferings and , than to those of mankind, as being so much less desire. I have the cool assumption of immorality for mainly from false to the great trusts in them, while these humbler ones as the dog, and horse, faithful unto death, unselfish and must be cut short in a honest and trues, , and uncomplaining.But this little note was not intended to afflict you with a discussion of the mighty of the which holds us all, big and little its mighty leash, I want to ask you, respected sir, to point me to the volume wherein I can find the excerpt and its is what I desire and if you will kindly help me I shall remain as nowYours gratefullyMarie WallaceGramercy Park HouseNew York Marie Wallace to Walt Whitman, [undated]
